issues.text: Can the wage structure fixed in a given industry be never revised to the prejudice of its workmen?

anchor.surface_text: Can the wage structure fixed in a given industry be never revised to the prejudice of its workmen? Considered as a general question in the abstract it must be answered in favour of Mr. Sen.

issues.text: Whether the Labour Appellate Tribunal was in error in assuming that it has been the convention in industrial adjudications not to reduce the existing emoluments of the workmen to their prejudice in any case.

anchor.surface_text: it has been the convention with industrial tribunals not to reduce the existing emoluments of the workmen to their prejudice. In the result the wage structure constituted by the tribunal was modified by the award of the appellate tribunal

issues.text: What is the true character of the concessional payments made by the appellant to its workmen and which have been incorporated by the Appellate Tribunal in the wage structure.
Whether the wage structure constituted by the Appellate Tribunal for existing workmen and new entrants creates two scales and is unjustified.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sen incidentally argued that the result of the award passed by the Labour Appellate Tribunal is that there will be two scales of wage structure, one for those who are already in the employment of the appellant and the other for the new entrants.

arguments.claim: Labour Appellate Tribunal erred in assuming a convention in industrial adjudications not to reduce existing emoluments of workmen to their prejudice in any case

anchor.surface_text: The view that the Appellate Tribunal has taken is that these so-called concessional payments have been enjoyed by the workmen for a pretty long time as of right

arguments.court_reasoning: No rigid convention; downward revision possible if wage above minimum and merits shown, balancing interests

arguments.claim: Wage structure revision permissible in favour of employer if financial position considerably deteriorated or other relevant factors indicate

anchor.surface_text: For the appellant Mr. Sen has contended that the Labour Appellate Tribunal was in error in assuming that it has been the convention in industrial adjudications not to reduce the existing emoluments of the workmen to their prejudice in any case. He contends that just as the rise in the cost of living index or similar relevant factors may justify the revision of the wage structure in favour of the workmen, so should the revision of the wage structure be permissible in favour of the employer in case the financial position of the employer has considerably deteriorated or other relevant factors indicate such a revision.

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed in principle; possible if above minimum wage and case made out on merits considering financial difficulties, retrenchment, duration

arguments.claim: Two hours concession, facility bonus, food concession are bounty gratuitously paid and could be withdrawn at pleasure

anchor.surface_text: The tribunal hold that the two hours concession, facility bonus and the food concession were in the nature of bounty gratuitously paid by the appellant and as such they could be withdrawn by the appellant at its pleasure.

arguments.court_reasoning: Payments enjoyed long as of right, part of wage structure per history, evidence, admissions

arguments.claim: Concessional payments enjoyed long time as of right, part of basic wages/dearness allowance, terms of service; convention not to reduce emoluments

anchor.surface_text: The view that the Appellate Tribunal has taken is that these so-called concessional payments have been enjoyed by the workmen for a pretty long time as of right and as part of their basic wages and dearness allowance and as such they have become a term of the conditions of their service. Besides, the appellate tribunal has observed that it has been the convention with industrial tribunals not to reduce the existing emoluments of the workmen to their prejudice.

arguments.court_reasoning: Accepted character as part of wages based on history/admissions; convention not rigid

arguments.claim: Concessional payments are bounty, not amounts paid as matter of right
arguments.court_reasoning: Genesis shows compensation/repeated payments; admissions in pleadings/evidence treat as part of wage structure

arguments.claim: Result of LAT award creates two scales of wage structure for existing vs new entrants, unjustified

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sen incidentally argued that the result of the award passed by the Labour Appellate Tribunal is that there will be two scales of wage structure, one for those who are already in the employment of the appellant and the other for the new entrants.

arguments.claim: Wage structure can be revised downward to prejudice of workmen if above bare minimum wage and case made out on merits

anchor.surface_text: The question posed before us by Mr. Sen is Can the wage structure fixed in a given industry be never revised to the prejudice of its workmen? Considered as a general question in the abstract it must be answered in favour of Mr. Sen.

arguments.claim: No industry right to exist unless able to pay bare minimum wage; cannot employ on starvation wages

anchor.surface_text: No industry has a right to exist unless it is able to pay its workmen at least a bare minimum wage. It is quite likely that in under-developed countries,

arguments.claim: LAT decision not based solely on convention; considered retrenchment improving finances, cost of living not sufficiently shown, wages at minimum/fair level
Concessional payments form part of basic wage and dearness allowance, not bounty
Appellant before Shri Palit resisted increment claiming additional components made ample provision for cost of living

anchor.surface_text: Shri Palit was, however, not impressed with this plea. He thought that by introducing these components in the wage structure the Managing Director chose to hold the key in his own hands so that he can manipulate the quantum of benefit under this head and could adjust it to the output in the factory.

arguments.court_reasoning: Consistent with treating as part of wages

holdings.text: The wage structure fixed in a given industry can be revised to the prejudice of its workmen if it is above the bare minimum wage and a case is made out on merits considering financial difficulties, retrenchment, duration, and balancing interests.
holdings.reasoning_summary: General principle clarified: revision possible above minimum wage if tribunal satisfied on merits after weighing financial position, retrenchment effects, duration of difficulties, harmony vs survival.

holdings.text: There is no rigid and inexorable convention that wage structure once fixed by industrial tribunals can never be changed to the prejudice of workmen.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Convention exists but not absolute; subject to merits and relevant considerations like those for upward revision.

holdings.text: No industry has a right to exist unless it is able to pay its workmen at least a bare minimum wage; employment on starvation wages cannot be encouraged in a welfare state.

anchor.surface_text: There is, however, one principle which admits of no exceptions. No industry has a right to exist unless it is able to pay its workmen at least a bare minimum wage. It is quite likely that in under-developed countries, where unemployment prevails on a very large scale, unorganised labour may be available on starvation wages but the employment of labour on starvation wages cannot be encouraged or favored in a modern democratic welfare state.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Absolute floor for wages derived from welfare state objectives; below minimum, enterprise cannot operate.

holdings.text: Concessional payments (two hours concession, facility bonus, food concession) are not bounty but form part of basic wage and dearness allowance; no reason to interfere with Appellate Tribunal's conclusion.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Based on genesis (compensation for reduced hours, high living costs), long enjoyment as right, admissions in pleadings and evidence, prior conduct before Palit and tribunals.

holdings.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal's decision not vitiated as not based solely on convention but also on retrenchment improving finances, insufficient evidence on cost of living fall, wages at minimum/fair level.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Multiple factors supported no reduction; court slow to interfere absent legal error or insufficient evidence.

holdings.text: Modifications by Labour Appellate Tribunal incorporating concessional payments into wage structure for existing workmen upheld; no need to consider new entrants' scale.
holdings.reasoning_summary: As challenge to existing workmen's benefits fails, incidental point on new entrants not decided.

holdings.text: Appeal fails; both contentions raised by appellant substantially fail.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Challenges to convention and payments' character rejected; LAT award upheld.

anchor.surface_text: The result is that both the contentions raised by Mr. Sen substantially fail.

outcome.relief_summary: Both contentions raised by the appellant (company) fail; no interference with Labour Appellate Tribunal's award upholding and modifying wage structure in favour of existing workmen by incorporating concessional payments.
